Dialogue.Page: Greetings.
You must be the one who gifted us the cockpit?

DialogueOption.Text: I think you have the wrong person.

Dialogue.Page: My clan and I express our gratitude.
The technology is suitable, yes. My clan and I thank you.
Have I brought the wrong person here?
How strange... it is rare for me to make a mistake like this. Perhaps I should escort you out of the village while I search for the correct person.
I see you are one for humor. Luckily, I too am fond of it.
You are fortunate in that I was not actually planning to do so.
What would you request of me?

DialogueOption.Text: Will you help us open the Great Door?
What do you know about the fifth shard?
Do you know where the other clans are?
What do you know about the fifth shard?
Do you know where the other clans are?
I'm glad you agreed to help us.
I'm glad you agreed to help us.

Dialogue.Page: The task you ask of me is a great one. You ask me to give up what my clan has treasured for years to aid you.

Nevertheless, you did aid our clan. It would seem like the logical course of action is to return that aid. There is also the undeniable fact that everyone is at least a little bit curious as to what lies behind the Great Door.
As clan leader, I make the decision that my clan will help you in your mission and lend you our shard.
Take our shard, and use its power to unite this torn world.
The tale of the fifth shard is a common story among this clan, though I believe a large portion of the story was told with some creative adjustments.

Given what I know from reading the old manuscripts, the fifth shard is rumored to be on the south pole. I do not know how much truth this holds, for my clan dare not venture into the southern territory.
I hope this knowledge aids you on your journey.
I know that there is one other Nomai clan on the northern hemisphere and two Inhabitant clans on the southern hemisphere.
I do not know their precise locations, however. I hope that is enough for you to find them.
The feeling is mutual. I hope convincing the other clans to join goes as smoothly as it did with mine, although I have my doubts.
I will see you at the Great Door, my friend.
The feeling is mutual. I will see you at the Great Door, my friend.
